dataset_name: IDEA (Individuals with Disabilities Education Act) Part B Special Education - Comprehensive National and State Data
data_source: U.S. Department of Education, Office of Special Education Programs (OSEP); National Center for Education Statistics (NCES)
data_enrichment_notes: Enriched dataset combining disability category trends (1976-2023), state-level enrollment (1990-2023), educational environment data, and multi-year analysis

disability_breakdown_historical.title: Children 3 to 21 years old served under IDEA, Part B, by type of disability: Selected school years, 1976-77 through 2022-23

state_level_by_age.title: Number and percentage of children served under IDEA, Part B, by age group and state or jurisdiction: Selected school years, 1990-91 through 2022-23

educational_environments.title: Percentage distribution of school-age students served under IDEA, Part B, by educational environment and type of disability

underlying_data.title: IDEA Section 618 State Part B Child Count and Educational Environments
underlying_data.note: Raw CSV files by year available from ED Open Data Platform

national_summary_2022_23.note: All-time high as of 2022-23; 3% higher than 2019-20 pre-pandemic levels

disability_categories_2022_23.description: Disorder in basic psychological processes involved in understanding or using language (includes dyslexia, dyscalculia, dysgraphia)
Communication disorder such as stuttering, impaired articulation, language or voice impairment
Limited strength, vitality, or alertness due to chronic or acute health problems (includes ADHD, epilepsy, asthma, diabetes, etc.)
Autism spectrum disorder significantly affecting communication and social interaction
disability_categories_2022_23.growth_note: Fastest-growing category; rose from 1.5% in 2000-01 to 13% in 2022-23

disability_categories_2022_23.description: Delay in physical, cognitive, communication, social/emotional, or adaptive development (ages 3-9)
disability_categories_2022_23.note: Optional by state law; not all states report this category

disability_categories_2022_23.description: Significantly subaverage general intellectual functioning concurrent with deficits in adaptive behavior
Condition exhibiting behavioral or emotional responses so different from age-appropriate norms that they adversely affect educational performance
Concomitant impairments whose combination causes severe educational needs
Impairment in hearing, whether permanent or fluctuating, including deafness
Severe orthopedic impairment adversely affecting educational performance
Impairment in vision that, even with correction, adversely affects educational performance (includes blindness)
Acquired injury to the brain caused by external physical force

key_findings: Total served grew 104% from 3.7 million (1976-77) to 7.5 million (2022-23)
Growth was most rapid 1976-2005 (129% increase), then plateaued 2005-2015, resumed 2015-present
COVID-19 caused temporary dip in 2020-21 (7.18M), but recovered to record 7.53M by 2022-23
As percentage of enrollment: rose from 8.3% (1976) to 15.2% (2023), an 83% increase
Peak growth rate: 1990s saw ~1.5-2% annual increases; 2010s-2020s averaged ~1% annual increases

autism.growth_pattern: Fastest-growing disability category; 8.5x increase from 2000-01 to 2022-23

specific_learning_disability.decline_note: Not due to fewer SLD students, but due to faster growth in other categories (autism, OHI)

other_health_impairment.growth_note: Primarily driven by increased ADHD identification; increased 3.2x from 2000-01 to 2022-23

speech_language_impairment.trend: Stable at ~20% since 2000; consistent second-largest category

developmental_delay.note: Optional state reporting category (ages 3-9 only); growth reflects both more children and more state adoption

variance_analysis.interpretation: Nearly 2:1 variation in state identification rates; likely reflects differences in state disability determination practices, SES levels, and special education policies

state_growth_analysis.interpretation: High-growth states (Utah, Nevada, Arizona) show 50%+ increases, likely from population growth and/or improved identification. Declining states face demographic challenges or more restrictive identification practices.

environment_descriptions.regular_class_80_plus_pct: Students spending 80% or more of the school day inside a regular classroom (fully included)
environment_descriptions.regular_class_40_to_79_pct: Students spending 40-79% of the school day inside a regular classroom (partial inclusion)
environment_descriptions.regular_class_less_than_40_pct: Students spending less than 40% of the school day inside a regular classroom (mostly resource/special classes)
environment_descriptions.separate_school: Separate school specifically for students with disabilities
environment_descriptions.separate_residential_facility: Separate residential facility for students with disabilities
environment_descriptions.parentally_placed_private_school: Students enrolled by parents in private schools who receive special education services at public expense
environment_descriptions.homebound_hospital: Students receiving education in homebound or hospital placement

educational_environments_2022.inclusion_rate_summary: 82.83% of students with disabilities spend at least some time in regular classrooms; 67% spend 80%+ of day in regular classes (highest inclusion level)

Specific learning disability.note: Highest inclusion rate of any disability

Speech or language impairment.note: Second-highest inclusion rate; mostly in regular class full-time

Intellectual disability.note: Lower inclusion; 45.5% spend <40% time in regular class

Emotional disturbance.note: Higher separate school placement (10.6%) and correctional facility placement

Multiple disabilities.note: Lowest inclusion rate; 43.5% in <40% regular class; 16.4% in separate schools

inclusion_trends_1989_2022.key_finding: Decade-long trend toward greater inclusion: 31.7% in 80%+ regular class (1989) to 67% (2022) — 111% increase in full inclusion rate

northeast_region.interpretation: Northeast has highest identification/service rates; may reflect better-funded school systems, higher awareness, or more inclusive policies

midwest_region.interpretation: Relatively high service rates; consistent with school funding and special education infrastructure

south_region.interpretation: Lower service rates; may reflect lower identification rates or different demographic/SES profiles

west_region.interpretation: Lower average driven by Hawaii (11.7%) and several mountain states; heterogeneous region

key_findings_and_insights: IDEA currently serves 7.5 million children (3-21 years old) in the U.S., representing 15.2% of total public school enrollment — an all-time high.
Autism is the fastest-growing disability category, increasing from 1.5% of IDEA students in 2000-01 to 13% in 2022-23 (8.5x growth in 23 years).
While autism has grown dramatically, overall IDEA enrollment growth has moderated: only 1% annually since 2015, compared to 2-3% in the 1990s-2000s.
Specific learning disability remains the largest category (32%) but has declined from 45% (2000-01), reflecting relative growth in autism and other health impairment identification.
Nearly 2:1 variation between states: Pennsylvania (21.1% of enrollment) vs. Hawaii (11.7%), suggesting significant differences in identification practices and/or population characteristics.
Inclusion in regular education has improved dramatically: 67% of students with disabilities now spend 80%+ of the day in regular classrooms, up from 31.7% in 1989.
Multiple disabilities and intellectual disability students have lowest inclusion rates (~35-49%); speech/language and SLD have highest inclusion rates (~93-95%).
COVID-19 caused brief enrollment dip in 2020-21 (7.18M) but rapid recovery to record 7.53M by 2022-23.

State growth analysis (2000-2023) shows highest growth in high-growth states (Utah 70%, Nevada 68%, Arizona 55%) and stagnation/decline in others (Hawaii -17%, Rhode Island -20%), reflecting population migration patterns.

Educational environment inequality: autism and multiple disability students have ~40% full inclusion vs. 76%+ for SLD and speech/language students, suggesting different service models by disability type.
data_limitations_and_notes: Data by disability type for Iowa are imputed based on 2018-19 percentages applied to 2022-23 totals
Educational environment data include 50 states and District of Columbia only (excludes U.S. territories)
Values are from NCES Digest of Education Statistics 2023 (prepared December 2023); 2023-24 data not yet available
United States total includes 50 states, DC, and Bureau of Indian Education
Other health impairment includes limited strength/vitality/alertness due to chronic or acute health problems (e.g., ADHD, epilepsy, asthma, diabetes); ADHD likely driving much of the growth
Developmental delay category is optional by state law; not all states report this category, leading to undercount nationally
Preschool disabled category (ages 3-5) tracked separately prior to 1990-91 and included in aggregate from 1990-91 forward
State identifications reflect state regulatory definitions of disability and identification practices, which vary substantially
Data represent 50 states + DC, but also include U.S. territories and Bureau of Indian Education in some national totals
Percent of enrollment calculated against total public K-12 enrollment from Common Core of Data (CCD)

autism_by_state_2022_23.note: Autism identification rates vary by state based on available NCES aggregate data
autism_by_state_2022_23.interpretation: States with higher overall IDEA rates tend to have higher autism identification, but the relationship is not perfectly linear

specific_learning_disability_by_state_20.note: SLD remains 32% of IDEA nationally, but varies by state
specific_learning_disability_by_state_20.interpretation: Some states over-identify SLD; others identify more broadly across disability categories
